tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login form using the 8-point grid system, focusing on proper alignment and spacing. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system).

Write down 5 common UX principles that you've seen in your portfolio or in design work, but don't fully understand. Research each principle and create a brief explanation of its purpose. (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics)
Sketch out 3 different error states for a login form, considering how they should be visually distinct from the main form. (Reference: Tesler’s Law)
Create a low-fidelity wireframe of your current portfolio's navigation, focusing on simplifying it and making it more intuitive. Use the 8-point grid system to ensure proper alignment.
Conduct 1 user interview using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document 3 pain points related to your design work. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/jobs-to-be-done)
Design a simple color palette for a hypothetical product, considering how colors can affect user experience. Use Aesthetic-Usability Effect as a reference point.
Create a high-fidelity wireframe of your portfolio's navigation, focusing on creating a seamless and intuitive experience. Use the 8-point grid system to ensure proper alignment.
Write a short reflection (max 500 words) on how you can apply Hick’s Law in your design work, considering how it affects user behavior. Reference https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law)
Design a simple icon set for a hypothetical product, focusing on creating consistent and recognizable icons.
Create a comprehensive design system document for your portfolio's navigation, including color palette, typography, spacing, and iconography. Use the 8-point grid system to ensure consistency.

Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document 5 pain points related to your design work. Create a brief analysis of how you can address each pain point in future projects.
Design a visually appealing and intuitive wireframe for a hypothetical product, focusing on creating a seamless user experience. Use all the UX principles learned throughout this plan as references.

resources.readup: As an emerging senior UX designer, you have a solid foundation in user research and collaboration, but there's room for growth in UI craft and visual design. Focus on developing your skills in these areas to elevate your portfolio and take on more complex projects, ultimately driving business value through user-centered design solutions.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Applying Hick's Law to Improve Navigation
topics.summary: Hick's Law states that the time it takes to make a decision is directly proportional to the number of options available. As an Emerging Senior, apply this principle to optimize navigation in a product or service, resulting in a more efficient user experience.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing websites or applications and identify areas where Hick's Law can be applied to improve navigation
Create a new wireframe of a navigation menu with a limited number of options (5-7) and test it for usability

topics.name: Conducting User Research using the Zeigarnik Effect
topics.summary: The Zeigarnik Effect suggests that unfinished tasks are more memorable than completed ones. As an Emerging Senior, use this principle to design a user research study that leaves users with a task or question to solve, increasing engagement and recall.
practice_points: Design a user research study using the Zeigarnik Effect, where participants complete a task and then are asked to reflect on their experience
Conduct 2-3 interviews using this approach and document findings

topics.name: Applying Tesler’s Law to Visual Design
topics.summary: Tesler's Law states that the more information presented, the less easily it can be understood. As an Emerging Senior, apply this principle to optimize visual design in a product or service, resulting in clearer communication and reduced cognitive load.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing visual designs (e.g., logos, icons, color schemes) and identify areas where Tesler's Law can be applied for improvement
Create a new visual design concept with limited information (2-3 key elements) and test it for usability

insights.brief: Emerging Seniors need to improve their foundational knowledge of UX principles, user behavior, and design tools.
insights.detailed: Current score of 69 indicates a need for improvement in understanding user needs, wireframing, prototyping, and usability testing. Emerging Seniors should focus on building a strong foundation in UX fundamentals to deliver high-quality designs.
actionable: Take online courses or attend workshops to improve knowledge of UX principles and design tools (e.g., Sketch, Figma, Adobe XD).
Read industry publications, blogs, and books to stay updated on the latest UX trends and best practices.
Join online communities or forums to connect with other designers and learn from their experiences.

insights.brief: Emerging Seniors need to enhance their visual design skills, including typography, color theory, and composition.
insights.detailed: Current score of 64 indicates a need for improvement in creating visually appealing designs that align with brand guidelines. Emerging Seniors should focus on developing their visual design skills to create consistent and effective UI/UX solutions.
actionable: Practice designing with a variety of typography, color schemes, and composition techniques to develop your visual design skills.

insights.brief: Emerging Seniors need to improve their user research skills, including conducting usability testing and gathering feedback.
insights.detailed: Current score of 77 indicates a strong foundation in user research, but Emerging Seniors should continue to refine their skills in conducting effective usability testing and gathering actionable feedback. This will enable them to deliver more informed design solutions.

insights.brief: Emerging Seniors need to develop their product thinking skills, including understanding user needs and business goals.
insights.detailed: Current score of 76 indicates a solid foundation in product thinking, but Emerging Seniors should continue to refine their skills in aligning design solutions with business objectives. This will enable them to deliver more effective and strategic designs.

insights.brief: Emerging Seniors need to improve their collaboration and communication skills, including working with cross-functional teams and presenting design solutions.
insights.detailed: Current score of 79 indicates a strong foundation in collaboration and communication, but Emerging Seniors should continue to refine their skills in effectively communicating design decisions and working with stakeholders. This will enable them to deliver more successful design outcomes.
